Award.AwardTitle: EAR-PF: A new archive of Paleoarchean ocean chemistry: the 3.24 Ga Panorama volcanogenic massive sulfide district, Western Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Benjamin Johnson has been granted an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out research and education plans at the University of Colorado. The investigation will focus on examining the biogeochemistry of altered oceanic crust from the Paleoarchean (3,400 to 3,200 million years ago), a crucial time in Earth evolution. Dr. Johnson will be deciphering the role of planetary geochemical and geologic processes on biological evolution and nutrient cycling. The education plan will focus on interacting with a wide range of audiences through programs at the University of Colorado sharing knowledge on early Earth and astrobiology. The PI will engage a diverse group of students through CU-Boulder's Summer Multicultural Access to Research Training (SMART) initiative, advise undergraduate research through the Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program (UROP), and promote science education by utilizing resources of the Science Education Initiative (SEI), SAGANet, and the Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Sciences (CIRES).

The overall goal of this research is to address four outstanding questions in biogeochemistry during the Paleoarchean: what controls the delta-18O value of Paleoarchean seawater? does hydrothermal circulation add or remove N from the Paleoarchean ocean? was sulfate in the Paleoarchean ocean high or low? and what is the depth of Paleoarchean mid-ocean ridges? While previous work has utilized sedimentary rock archives to elucidate Paleoarchean mineral chemistry and surface conditions, in this project, the PI will use a new archive of Paleoarchean mineral chemistry: hydrothermal deposits. Specifically, the 3.24 Ga Panorama volcanogenic massive sulfide (VMS) district in Western Australia, which represents a remarkably complete section of hydrothermally altered oceanic crust, including heat source, a 7 km thick outcrop of volcanic crust, and sedimentary cover serves as an archive of Paleoarchean biogeochemistry. The area has been investigated by the economic geology community, but has of yet not been utilized to answer questions of Earth history.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the Archean Eon, between 4 and 2.5 billion years ago, life on Earth became widespread. We don?t really know, however, exactly what the planet looked like at this time. How deep was the ocean?What nutrients were available and how did the cycle? How much land was above sea level? Usually, sedimentary rocks, such as limestone and chert, are used to record such conditions. Such sedimentary rocks, however, are liable to be altered from their original composition, especially if they are very old.

 

In this project, we used a different rock as a record of the ancient ocean ? ocean crust. That is, rocks that were on the bottom of the ocean, and that interacted with seawater. So even though there is no ancient ocean water, we have the rocks that interacted with it. Specifically, we studied a section of 3.2 billion year old crust from the Pilbara Craton in Australia from a place called the Panorama district. This area preserves five ancient hydrothermal cells, and is a wonderful cross-section of the ancient ocean crust.

 

We used measurements of oxygen isotopes from this crust, and constructed a model that can "undo" the alteration, to estimate the oxygen isotope composition of the ocean 3.2 billion years ago.

Oxygen comes in three different masses ? 16, 17, and 18 - and the ratio of these to each other in seawater reflects two key processes: hydrothermal alteration of seafloor and weathering of continents. That is, interaction of water and rock in the ocean and on land. If either of these processes changes, or is absent, then the ocean will have a distinct oxygen isotope composition. Oxygen isotope data is presented in permil (‰) notation, which is the ratio of the heaviest isotope of oxygen -18 -  to the lightest - 16 - compared to a standard. Today, the value for the ocean is -1‰. In our study, we found that the seawater 3.2 billion years ago has a value of +3‰, or 4‰ different than today!

 

We suggest that the reason for this difference is that there was no land emergent above sea level. That is, the Earth was a water world. When rain and snow falls on land, it interacts with the rocks and locks away oxygen-18 into the crust. The water that flows back to the oceans in rivers is therefore depleted in oxygen-18, and the ocean value becomes lower. If this process is not happening, as we suggest, the ocean should be enriched, or higher in oxygen-18, and this is in fact what we see from the rocks in Australia!

 

So, the early Earth appears to have been a water world. There appear to have been no significant areas of land above sea level until after 3.2 billion years ago. This has bearing on how early life on the planet evolved and distributed.
